Award.AwardTitle: Symposium on Science and Technology Driving the Bioeconomy

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award is partial support of the Symposium on Stakeholders Perspective on the Bioeconomy as part of the meeting of the USDA S-1075 Multistate Committee. The biobased economy has potential to produce biofuels and bioproducts in an environmentally sustainable way. This consortia of researchers from 35 land grant universities address barriers to a bioeconomy including challenges in feedstock logistics and conversion technologies.

Annual meetings of the S-1045 multistate committee are held to coordinate and share research from land grant universities across the nation. Symposiums are organized with leading researchers and speakers from funding agencies to share the latest research knowledge and coordinate future research. The 2019 S-1075 Multistate Committee annual symposium will be held at the USDOE National Renewable Energy Laboratory (NREL) on July 29-30, 2019. The goal of the 2019 symposium is to develop an understanding of the key challenges when trying to commercialize bioenergy and bioproduct technologies. NSF funding will be used to support graduate students to attend this symposium and to meet with NREL researchers. This is a meeting where the students can interact with the entire sector of the bioeconomy including researchers, producers, processors, financial sector and government agencies. This will help in orienting the next workforce generation to challenges and opportunities in the bioeconomy. The proceedings from the symposium will be published in both hard and soft copy formats and distributed widely to interested audience by S-1045 members.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

ProgramElement.Text: Proc Sys, Reac Eng & Mol Therm

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to introduce graduate students to the DOE National Laboratory system by providing travel awards to visit the National Renewable Energy Laboratory (NREL) in Golden, Colorado while at the S-1075 Symposium on The Science and Engineering for a Biobased Industry and Economy.  Students awarded NSF travel funds attended the symposium along with faculty from participating land grant universities.  NREL scientists and engineers presented at this symposium and then attended a poster session that featured graduate student research.  Students then toured the NREL facilities, viewing both biochemical and thermochemical pilot facilities that are used for making fuels and chemicals.  Graduate students interacted and networked with NREL scientists and engineers while at the symposium and while touring NREL's facilities.

 

Professional development was afforded to 18 graduate students from U.S. universities who attended the symposium and tour of NREL.  Students gained knowledge from NREL scientists and engineers who presented their work regarding biomass conversion to fuels and valuable products.  Presentations regarding biomass characterization, photoautotrophic biocatalysis, muconic acid production, electrobiochemical methane production, co-processing of bio-oils with petroleum, and plastics upcycling were provided by NREL.  Graduate students presented posters to hone their communication skills while networking with NREL staff and faculty and students from other universities.  Tours of the biochemical platform and thermochemical platform pilot R&D areas at NREL allowed students to see the extent of de-risking that is performed as bench-scale experiments are scaled to larger production levels.  The knowledge gained by graduate students during this two day event will aid them in making future career decisions as NREL's presentations and tours provided a "state-of-the-art" overview of fuel and chemical production from biomass.  By viewing NREL's capabilities, NSF awarded graduate students are now better able to collaborate with DOE National Laboratories in their future work.  These collaboration's will further student training, ensuring that the next generation of scientists and engineers are even more prepared for converting plant biomass into fuels and chemicals.  As many technologies stall in the development pipeline, inspiring more people with more ideas will increase the likelihood that bioenergy and bioproduct technologies will achieve commercialization.  Economic benefits will then reward biomass producing communities and their biorefineries as biobased products enter the market.   

 

 


Last Modified: 12/05/2019
Modified by: Christopher M Saffron

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The goal of this project was to introduce graduate students to the DOE National Laboratory system by providing travel awards to visit the National Renewable Energy Laboratory (NREL) in Golden, Colorado while at the S-1075 Symposium on The Science and Engineering for a Biobased Industry and Economy. Students awarded NSF travel funds attended the symposium along with faculty from participating land grant universities. NREL scientists and engineers presented at this symposium and then attended a poster session that featured graduate student research. Students then toured the NREL facilities, viewing both biochemical and thermochemical pilot facilities that are used for making fuels and chemicals. Graduate students interacted and networked with NREL scientists and engineers while at the symposium and while touring NREL's facilities. Professional development was afforded to 18 graduate students from U.S. universities who attended the symposium and tour of NREL. Students gained knowledge from NREL scientists and engineers who presented their work regarding biomass conversion to fuels and valuable products. Presentations regarding biomass characterization, photoautotrophic biocatalysis, muconic acid production, electrobiochemical methane production, co-processing of bio-oils with petroleum, and plastics upcycling were provided by NREL. Graduate students presented posters to hone their communication skills while networking with NREL staff and faculty and students from other universities. Tours of the biochemical platform and thermochemical platform pilot R&D areas at NREL allowed students to see the extent of de-risking that is performed as bench-scale experiments are scaled to larger production levels. The knowledge gained by graduate students during this two day event will aid them in making future career decisions as NREL's presentations and tours provided a "state-of-the-art" overview of fuel and chemical production from biomass. By viewing NREL's capabilities, NSF awarded graduate students are now better able to collaborate with DOE National Laboratories in their future work. These collaboration's will further student training, ensuring that the next generation of scientists and engineers are even more prepared for converting plant biomass into fuels and chemicals. As many technologies stall in the development pipeline, inspiring more people with more ideas will increase the likelihood that bioenergy and bioproduct technologies will achieve commercialization. Economic benefits will then reward biomass producing communities and their biorefineries as biobased products enter the market. Last Modified: 12/05/2019 Submitted by: Christopher M Saffron
